>>>>> "Ralf" == Ralf Krakowski <ralf.krakowski@...> writes:

Hi, Ralf,

I think may I know what may be causing this problem. You don't say which
version of junit you're using, but I suspect it is not 3.6.

I believe what is happening is that you are seeing the different
behaviors associated with the different ClassLoaders used by the
textui and swingui front ends. The textui uses the standard system
ClassLoader to create all classes. The swingui gives you the option of
using JUnit's own custom ClassLoader to reload classes that have
changed between invocations of the test.

The ClassCastException you're seeing could be due attempting to cast
an object that has been loaded through the custom ClassLoader to a
reference to an object that was created through a different
ClassLoader. This would cause this exact outcome.

To fix this, try starting junit with the -noloading flag from the
command line. If this fixes your behavior, then you can continue doing
this, but you have to restart junit every time you change your
code. Or you can search in the archives for this group for
excluded.properties. There have been several messages sent that
describe how to use this file to tell the custom ClassLoader to ignore
certain package hierarchies and let the system ClassLoader deal with
them. That is probably a better long term solution.

bab
